Our highlight color when you emoji react is not very visible. We should make it less subtle.

slack zulip
non-selected slack non-selected zulip
In particular, our outline thickness (and possibly color, hard to tell) remain the same, whereas on Slack it goes from no outline to ~2px (?) outline, and the color change is more noticeable
(forked from #design > emoji reactions with names)
Our dark mode is even worse, we don't change it to any sort of blue color, it's just a darker black.
discord unselected zulip unselected discord selected zulip selected
Anyone want to play around with fixing this?
I would like to pick this up.
would raise a PR improving it, asap

Some other misc tweaks that might be good:

  • As mentioned above, make the outline slightly thicker
  • Try bumping up the text thickness a tiny bit? I'm not sure if that would look good, but it'd be interesting to try it.

Do browser do subpixel border widths? Firefox rounds it down, and I think other browsers do as well. I think we should go with a integer number of pixels.

One other thing is that the horizontal padding looks slightly uneven, I think because the emoji has more space on the left side? We might want to increase the right padding a bit, so that it looks nicer in the normal cases (obviously it won't look nice for every custom emoji/etc, but we can do our best)

image.png

If we go with integer number of pixels with border-width then it's already 1px, and it won't look good at all with 2px.

Tried with giving a max-width to emoji part!
Please let me know about thoughts on it.

It looks good to me! And yeah, I went and tried the 2px border and it doesn't look great. I think one thing that maybe makes the borders appear larger on other apps is that their corners are more rounded? We might want to try that out.
I'd also love to see similar changes for dark mode :)
image.png

Thoughts ? Alya Abbott Wesley Aptekar-Cassels
I think that's going a little too far on the rounded edges — I actually like that ours are kinda square, I think they should just be a tiny bit more rounded than they are currently

For dark mode, I think the background colors are too harsh — I'd want a light grey for when they're unselected, and a medium shade of blue when they are selected. I'd aim for a relatively similar level of contrast between the background and the foreground in both light and dark modes.

I would keep the corner rounding the same as it currently is for the purposes of this discussion. I think it's pretty independent from what we're playing with here, and will be a something we can come back to when we have a plan for #design > emoji reactions with names .
In general, let's try a minimal number of changes to address the UX goal of making it easier to see what reactions the user has selected. Otherwise, it makes it much harder to review/think about.

Could you post screenshots with the following minimal changes, that don't otherwise play with spacing or emoji the user didn't upvote?

For light mode:

  1. More distinct blue border (could show a couple of different thickness options)
  2. Blue font on the number, with and without making it bolder
  3. If you want to play with how blue the background is, that's fine too

For dark mode, the blue background really isn't working for me. I'd be interested to see a blue outline version similar to Discord's.
Once we have ideas we're pretty happy with, we should also look at them on different backgrounds (PMs, @-mentions).

Would playing with depth via box-shadows be a bad idea? @Steve Howell (showell) #general > Flatland ?

depth

Some random discussion thread with philosophical musings about humans being 3D, is not a reason to unilaterally take a tiny part of the UI in a different design direction that’s inconsistent with the rest of the UI.

Zulip isn’t flat because it was developed by a team of two-dimensional flatworms. It’s flat because modern design is all about cutting out unnecessary noise. We have a long way to go before anyone will think of our design as “modern”, but the trend towards flatness is industry-wide and that isn’t an accident.

I remember this specific aspect of emoji reaction design being a thing that required a lot of care and constrained design options.
